00028 namespace GeographicLib {
00029 
00030   class GravityCircle;
00031 
00032   /**
00033    * \brief Model of the earth's gravity field
00034    *
00035    * Evaluate the earth's gravity field according to a model.  The supported
00036    * models treat only the gravitational field exterior to the mass of the
00037    * earth.  When computing the field at points near (but above) the surface of
00038    * the earth a small correction can be applied to account for the mass of the
00039    * atomsphere above the point in question; see \ref gravityatmos.
00040    * Determining the geoid height entails correcting for the mass of the earth
00041    * above the geoid.  The egm96 and egm2008 include separate correction terms
00042    * to account for this mass.
00043    *
00044    * Definitions and terminology (from Heiskanen and Moritz, Sec 2-13):
00045    * - \e V = gravitational potential;
00046    * - \e Phi = rotational potential;
00047    * - \e W = \e V + \e Phi = \e T + \e U = total potential;
00048    * - <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> = normal gravitation potential;
00049    * - \e U = <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> + \e Phi = total normal potential;
00050    * - \e T = \e W - \e U = \e V - <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> = anomalous or
00051    *   disturbing potential;
00052    * - <b>g</b> = <b>grad</b> \e W = <b>gamma</b> + <b>delta</b>;
00053    * - <b>f</b> = <b>grad</b> \e Phi;
00054    * - <b>Gamma</b> = <b>grad</b> <i>V</i><sub>0</sub>;
00055    * - <b>gamma</b> = <b>grad</b> \e U;
00056    * - <b>delta</b> = <b>grad</b> \e T = gravity disturbance vector
00057    *   = <b>g</b><sub><i>P</i></sub> - <b>gamma</b><sub><i>P</i></sub>;
00058    * - delta \e g = gravity disturbance = \e g<sub><i>P</i></sub> - \e
00059    *   gamma<sub><i>P</i></sub>;
00060    * - Delta <b>g</b> = gravity anomaly vector =
00061    *   <b>g</b><sub><i>P</i></sub> - <b>gamma</b><sub><i>Q</i></sub>; here the
00062    *   line \e PQ is perpendicular to ellipsoid and the potential at \e P
00063    *   equals the normal potential at \e Q;
00064    * - Delta \e g = gravity anomaly = \e g<sub><i>P</i></sub> - \e
00065    *   gamma<sub><i>Q</i></sub>;
00066    * - (\e xi, \e eta) deflection of the vertical, the difference in
00067    *   directions of <b>g</b><sub><i>P</i></sub> and
00068    *   <b>gamma</b><sub><i>Q</i></sub>, \e xi = NS, \e eta = EW.
00069    * - \e X, \e Y, \e Z, geocentric coordinates;
00070    * - \e x, \e y, \e z, local cartesian coordinates used to denote the east,
00071    *   north and up directions.
00072    *
00073    * See \ref gravity for details of how to install the gravity model and the
00074    * data format.
00075    *
00076    * References:
00077    * - W. A. Heiskanen and H. Moritz, Physical Geodesy (Freeman, San
00078    *   Francisco, 1967).
00079    **********************************************************************/
00080 
00081   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT GravityModel {
00082   private:
00083     typedef Math::real real;
00084     friend class GravityCircle;
00085     static const int idlength_ = 8;
00086     std::string _name, _dir, _description, _date, _filename, _id;
00087     real _amodel, _GMmodel, _zeta0, _corrmult;
00088     SphericalHarmonic::normalization _norm;
00089     NormalGravity _earth;
00090     std::vector<real> _C, _S, _CC, _CS, _zonal;
00091     real _dzonal0;              // A left over contribution to _zonal.
00092     SphericalHarmonic _gravitational;
00093     SphericalHarmonic1 _disturbing;
00094     SphericalHarmonic _correction;
00095     void ReadMetadata(const std::string& name);
00096     Math::real InternalT(real X, real Y, real Z,
00097                          real& deltaX, real& deltaY, real& deltaZ,
00098                          bool gradp, bool correct) const throw();
00099     enum captype {
00100       CAP_NONE   = 0U,
00101       CAP_G      = 1U<<0,       // implies potentials W and V
00102       CAP_T      = 1U<<1,
00103       CAP_DELTA  = 1U<<2 | CAP_T, // delta implies T?
00104       CAP_C      = 1U<<3,
00105       CAP_GAMMA0 = 1U<<4,
00106       CAP_GAMMA  = 1U<<5,
00107       CAP_ALL    = 0x3FU,
00108     };
00109 
00110   public:
00111 
00112     /**
00113      * Bit masks for the capabilities to be given to the GravityCircle object
00114      * produced by Circle.
00115      **********************************************************************/
00116     enum mask {
00117       /**
00118        * No capabilities.
00119        * @hideinitializer
00120        **********************************************************************/
00121       NONE = 0U,
00122       /**
00123        * Allow calls to GravityCircle::Gravity, GravityCircle::W, and
00124        * GravityCircle::V.
00125        * @hideinitializer
00126        **********************************************************************/
00127       GRAVITY = CAP_G,
00128       /**
00129        * Allow calls to GravityCircle::Disturbance and GravityCircle::T.
00130        * @hideinitializer
00131        **********************************************************************/
00132       DISTURBANCE = CAP_DELTA,
00133       /**
00134        * Allow calls to GravityCircle::T(real lon) (i.e., computing the
00135        * disturbing potential and not the gravity disturbance vector).
00136        * @hideinitializer
00137        **********************************************************************/
00138       DISTURBING_POTENTIAL = CAP_T,
00139       /**
00140        * Allow calls to GravityCircle::SphericalAnomaly.
00141        * @hideinitializer
00142        **********************************************************************/
00143       SPHERICAL_ANOMALY = CAP_DELTA | CAP_GAMMA,
00144       /**
00145        * Allow calls to GravityCircle::GeoidHeight.
00146        * @hideinitializer
00147        **********************************************************************/
00148       GEOID_HEIGHT = CAP_T | CAP_C | CAP_GAMMA0,
00149       /**
00150        * All capabilities.
00151        * @hideinitializer
00152        **********************************************************************/
00153       ALL = CAP_ALL,
00154     };
00155     /** \name Setting up the gravity model
00156      **********************************************************************/
00157     ///@{
00158     /**
00159      * Construct a gravity model.
00160      *
00161      * @param[in] name the name of the model.
00162      * @param[in] path (optional) directory for data file.
00163      *
00164      * A filename is formed by appending ".egm" (World Gravity Model) to the
00165      * name.  If \e path is specified (and is non-empty), then the file is
00166      * loaded from directory, \e path.  Otherwise the path is given by
00167      * DefaultGravityPath().  This may throw an exception because the file does
00168      * not exist, is unreadable, or is corrupt.
00169      *
00170      * This file contains the metadata which specifies the properties of the
00171      * model.  The coefficients for the spherical harmonic sums are obtained
00172      * from a file obtained by appending ".cof" to metadata file (so the
00173      * filename ends in ".egm.cof").
00174      **********************************************************************/
00175     explicit GravityModel(const std::string& name,
00176                           const std::string& path = "");
00177     ///@}
00178 
00179     /** \name Compute gravity in geodetic coordinates
00180      **********************************************************************/
00181     ///@{
00182     /**
00183      * Evaluate the gravity at an arbitrary point above (or below) the
00184      * ellipsoid.
00185      *
00186      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00187      * @param[in] lon the geographic longitude (degrees).
00188      * @param[in] h the height above the ellipsoid (meters).
00189      * @param[out] gx the easterly component of the acceleration
00190      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00191      * @param[out] gy the northerly component of the acceleration
00192      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00193      * @param[out] gz the upward component of the acceleration
00194      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>); this is usually negative.
00195      * @return \e W the sum of the gravitational and centrifugal potentials.
00196      *
00197      * The function includes the effects of the earth's rotation.
00198      **********************************************************************/
00199     Math::real Gravity(real lat, real lon, real h,
00200                        real& gx, real& gy, real& gz) const throw();
00201 
00202     /**
00203      * Evaluate the gravity disturbance vector at an arbitrary point above (or
00204      * below) the ellipsoid.
00205      *
00206      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00207      * @param[in] lon the geographic longitude (degrees).
00208      * @param[in] h the height above the ellipsoid (meters).
00209      * @param[out] deltax the easterly component of the disturbance vector
00210      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00211      * @param[out] deltay the northerly component of the disturbance vector
00212      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00213      * @param[out] deltaz the upward component of the disturbance vector
00214      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00215      * @return \e T the corresponding disturbing potential.
00216      **********************************************************************/
00217     Math::real Disturbance(real lat, real lon, real h,
00218                            real& deltax, real& deltay, real& deltaz)
00219       const throw();
00220 
00221     /**
00222      * Evaluate the geoid height.
00223      *
00224      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00225      * @param[in] lon the geographic longitude (degrees).
00226      * @return \e N the height of the geoid above the ReferenceEllipsoid()
00227      *   (meters).
00228      *
00229      * This calls NormalGravity::U for ReferenceEllipsoid().  Some
00230      * approximations are made in computing the geoid height so that the
00231      * results of the NGA codes are reproduced accurately.  Details are given
00232      * in \ref gravitygeoid.
00233      **********************************************************************/
00234     Math::real GeoidHeight(real lat, real lon) const throw();
00235 
00236     /**
00237      * Evaluate the components of the gravity anomaly vector using the
00238      * spherical approximation.
00239      *
00240      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00241      * @param[in] lon the geographic longitude (degrees).
00242      * @param[in] h the height above the ellipsoid (meters).
00243      * @param[out] Dg01 the gravity anomaly (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00244      * @param[out] xi the northerly component of the deflection of the vertical
00245      *  (degrees).
00246      * @param[out] eta the easterly component of the deflection of the vertical
00247      *  (degrees).
00248      *
00249      * The spherical approximation (see Heiskanen and Moritz, Sec 2-14) is used
00250      * so that the results of the NGA codes are reproduced accurately.
00251      * approximations used here.  Details are given in \ref gravitygeoid.
00252      **********************************************************************/
00253     void SphericalAnomaly(real lat, real lon, real h,
00254                           real& Dg01, real& xi, real& eta) const throw();
00255     ///@}
00256 
00257     /** \name Compute gravity in geocentric coordinates
00258      **********************************************************************/
00259     ///@{
00260     /**
00261      * Evaluate the components of the acceleration due to gravity and the
00262      * centrifugal acceleration in geocentric coordinates.
00263      *
00264      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00265      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00266      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00267      * @param[out] gX the \e X component of the acceleration
00268      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00269      * @param[out] gY the \e Y component of the acceleration
00270      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00271      * @param[out] gZ the \e Z component of the acceleration
00272      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00273      * @return \e W = \e V + \e Phi the sum of the gravitational and
00274      *   centrifugal potentials (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00275      *
00276      * This calls NormalGravity::U for  ReferenceEllipsoid().
00277      **********************************************************************/
00278     Math::real W(real X, real Y, real Z,
00279                  real& gX, real& gY, real& gZ) const throw();
00280 
00281     /**
00282      * Evaluate the components of the acceleration due to gravity in geocentric
00283      * coordinates.
00284      *
00285      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00286      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00287      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00288      * @param[out] GX the \e X component of the acceleration
00289      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00290      * @param[out] GY the \e Y component of the acceleration
00291      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00292      * @param[out] GZ the \e Z component of the acceleration
00293      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00294      * @return \e V = \e W - \e Phi the gravitational potential
00295      *   (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00296      **********************************************************************/
00297     Math::real V(real X, real Y, real Z,
00298                  real& GX, real& GY, real& GZ) const throw();
00299 
00300     /**
00301      * Evaluate the components of the gravity disturbance in geocentric
00302      * coordinates.
00303      *
00304      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00305      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00306      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00307      * @param[out] deltaX the \e X component of the gravity disturbance
00308      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00309      * @param[out] deltaY the \e Y component of the gravity disturbance
00310      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00311      * @param[out] deltaZ the \e Z component of the gravity disturbance
00312      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00313      * @return \e T = \e W - \e U the disturbing potential (also called the
00314      *   anomalous potential) (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00315      **********************************************************************/
00316     Math::real T(real X, real Y, real Z,
00317                  real& deltaX, real& deltaY, real& deltaZ) const throw()
00318     { return InternalT(X, Y, Z, deltaX, deltaY, deltaZ, true, true); }
00319 
00320     /**
00321      * Evaluate disturbing potential in geocentric coordinates.
00322      *
00323      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00324      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00325      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00326      * @return \e T = \e W - \e U the disturbing potential (also called the
00327      *   anomalous potential) (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00328      **********************************************************************/
00329     Math::real T(real X, real Y, real Z) const throw() {
00330       real dummy;
00331       return InternalT(X, Y, Z, dummy, dummy, dummy, false, true);
00332     }
00333 
00334     /**
00335      * Evaluate the components of the acceleration due to normal gravity and the
00336      * centrifugal acceleration in geocentric coordinates.
00337      *
00338      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00339      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00340      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00341      * @param[out] gammaX the \e X component of the normal acceleration
00342      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00343      * @param[out] gammaY the \e Y component of the normal acceleration
00344      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00345      * @param[out] gammaZ the \e Z component of the normal acceleration
00346      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00347      * @return \e U = <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> + \e Phi the sum of the
00348      *   normal gravitational and centrifugal potentials
00349      *   (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00350      *
00351      * This calls NormalGravity::U for  ReferenceEllipsoid().
00352      **********************************************************************/
00353     Math::real U(real X, real Y, real Z,
00354                  real& gammaX, real& gammaY, real& gammaZ) const throw()
00355     { return _earth.U(X, Y, Z, gammaX, gammaY, gammaZ); }
00356 
00357     /**
00358      * Evaluate the centrifugal acceleration in geocentric coordinates.
00359      *
00360      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00361      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00362      * @param[out] fX the \e X component of the centrifugal acceleration
00363      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00364      * @param[out] fY the \e Y component of the centrifugal acceleration
00365      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00366      * @return \e Phi the centrifugal potential (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00367      *
00368      * This calls NormalGravity::Phi for  ReferenceEllipsoid().
00369      **********************************************************************/
00370     Math::real Phi(real X, real Y, real& fX, real& fY) const throw()
00371     { return _earth.Phi(X, Y, fX, fY); }
00372     ///@}
00373 
00374     /** \name Compute gravity on a circle of constant latitude
00375      **********************************************************************/
00376     ///@{
00377     /**
00378      * Create a GravityCircle object to allow the gravity field at many points
00379      * with constant \e lat and \e h and varying \e lon to be computed
00380      * efficiently.
00381      *
00382      * @param[in] lat latitude of the point (degrees).
00383      * @param[in] h the height of the point above the ellipsoid (meters).
00384      * @param[in] caps bitor'ed combination of GravityModel::mask values
00385      *   specifying the capabilities of the resulting GravityCircle object.
00386      * @return a GravityCircle object whose member functions computes the
00387      *   gravitational field at a particular values of \e lon.
00388      *
00389      * The GravityModel::mask values are
00390      * - \e caps |= GravityModel::GRAVITY
00391      * - \e caps |= GravityModel::DISTURBANCE
00392      * - \e caps |= GravityModel::DISTURBING_POTENTIAL
00393      * - \e caps |= GravityModel::SPHERICAL_ANOMALY
00394      * - \e caps |= GravityModel::GEOID_HEIGHT
00395      * .
00396      * The default value of \e caps is GravityModel::ALL which turns on all the
00397      * capabilities.  If an unsupported function is invoked, it will return
00398      * NaNs.  Note that GravityModel::GEOID_HEIGHT will only be honored if \e h
00399      * = 0.
00400      *
00401      * If the field at several points on a circle of latitude need to be
00402      * calculated then instead of
00403      \code
00404   GravityModel g(...);          // Create a gravity model
00405   double lat = 33, lon0 = 44, dlon = 0.01;
00406   for (int i = 0; i <= 100; ++i) {
00407     real lon = lon0 + i * dlon;
00408     std::cout << lon << " " << g.GeoidHeight(lat, lon) << "\n";
00409   }
00410      \endcode
00411      * use a GravityCircle as in
00412      \code
00413   GravityModel g(...);          // Create a gravity model
00414   double lat = 33, lon0 = 44, dlon = 0.01;
00415   GravityCircle c(g.Circle(lat, 0)); // the GravityCircle object
00416   for (int i = 0; i <= 100; ++i) {
00417     real lon = lon0 + i * dlon;
00418     std::cout << lon << " " << c.GeoidHeight(lon) << "\n";
00419   }
00420      \endcode
00421      * For high-degree models, this will be substantially faster.  See \ref
00422      * gravityparallel for an example of using GravityCircle (together with
00423      * OpenMP) to speed up the computation of geoid heights.
00424      **********************************************************************/
00425     GravityCircle Circle(real lat, real h, unsigned caps = ALL) const;
00426     ///@}
00427 
00428     /** \name Inspector functions
00429      **********************************************************************/
00430     ///@{
00431 
00432     /**
00433      * @return the NormalGravity object for the reference ellipsoid.
00434      **********************************************************************/
00435     const NormalGravity& ReferenceEllipsoid() const throw() { return _earth; }
00436 
00437     /**
00438      * @return the description of the gravity model, if available, in the data
00439      *   file; if absent, return "NONE".
00440      **********************************************************************/
00441     const std::string& Description() const throw() { return _description; }
00442 
00443     /**
00444      * @return date of the model; if absent, return "UNKNOWN".
00445      **********************************************************************/
00446     const std::string& DateTime() const throw() { return _date; }
00447 
00448     /**
00449      * @return full file name used to load the gravity model.
00450      **********************************************************************/
00451     const std::string& GravityFile() const throw() { return _filename; }
00452 
00453     /**
00454      * @return "name" used to load the gravity model (from the first argument
00455      *   of the constructor, but this may be overridden by the model file).
00456      **********************************************************************/
00457     const std::string& GravityModelName() const throw() { return _name; }
00458 
00459     /**
00460      * @return directory used to load the gravity model.
00461      **********************************************************************/
00462     const std::string& GravityModelDirectory() const throw() { return _dir; }
00463 
00464     /**
00465      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).
00466      **********************************************************************/
00467     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _earth.MajorRadius(); }
00468 
00469     /**
00470      * @return \e GM the mass constant of the model
00471      *   (m<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>); this is the product of \e G the
00472      *   gravitational constant and \e M the mass of the earth (usually
00473      *   including the mass of the earth's atmosphere).
00474      **********************************************************************/
00475     Math::real MassConstant() const throw() { return _GMmodel; }
00476 
00477     /**
00478      * @return \e GM the mass constant of the ReferenceEllipsoid()
00479      *   (m<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00480      **********************************************************************/
00481     Math::real ReferenceMassConstant() const throw()
00482     { return _earth.MassConstant(); }
00483 
00484     /**
00485      * @return \e omega the angular velocity of the model and the
00486      *   ReferenceEllipsoid() (rad s<sup>-1</sup>).
00487      **********************************************************************/
00488     Math::real AngularVelocity() const throw()
00489     { return _earth.AngularVelocity(); }
00490 
00491     /**
00492      * @return \e f the flattening of the ellipsoid.
00493      **********************************************************************/
00494     Math::real Flattening() const throw() { return _earth.Flattening(); }
00495     ///@}
00496 
00497     /**
00498      * @return the default path for gravity model data files.
00499      *
00500      * This is the value of the environment variable GRAVITY_PATH, if set;
00501      * otherwise, it is $GEOGRAPHICLIB_DATA/gravity if the environment variable
00502      * GEOGRAPHICLIB_DATA is set; otherwise, it is a compile-time default
00503      * (/usr/local/share/GeographicLib/gravity on non-Windows systems and
00504      * C:/Documents and Settings/All Users/Application
00505      * Data/GeographicLib/gravity on Windows systems).
00506      **********************************************************************/
00507     static std::string DefaultGravityPath();
00508 
00509     /**
00510      * @return the default name for the gravity model.
00511      *
00512      * This is the value of the environment variable GRAVITY_NAME, if set,
00513      * otherwise, it is "egm96".  The GravityModel class does not use
00514      * this function; it is just provided as a convenience for a calling
00515      * program when constructing a GravityModel object.
00516      **********************************************************************/
00517     static std::string DefaultGravityName();
00518   };
00519
